Meta.title: Room 1
Meta.body:
This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen

Continue

Meta.title: Room 2
Meta.body:
Wow. What is this sensation?

Either someone sneakily wrapped you up in a massive gin soaked cloth and battered your fragile carcass with a hammer, or last night must have been pretty good fun.

What do I remember? Not much. Run a systems check: numb and sore in almost equal measures, with an acute, cold and/or wet feeling on the right temple. Brain must be functioning as these thoughts exist, but you can't really give it much more credit that that. A good night.

You suppose it is time to open your eyes and face whatever music you scored last night.

Meta.title: Room 3
Meta.body:
Oh God.

The shattered remenants of a...spaceship? cockpit lay all around you. A cracked window displays what would be a beautiful desktop background: stars, swirling nebula, ringed planets. Below this a toolbar of destruction unfolds.

Mangled steel, shattered glass. What isn't broken is covered in a viscous, dark blood. You examine your body, looking for wounds and trying to avoid looking at everything else. Not my blood, you think. Where am I? What the hell happened here? Whose blood is this?

The uncertainty tumbles and scrabbles with the more pressing questions of the here and now, leaving no room for emotion...yet. You notice a monitor still flickering in the corner, the last vestige of life in this dead room.

Do you want to go over and look at the monitor, or turn round and explore the rest of your strange location?

Meta.title: Room 4a
Meta.body:
You shift your ailing body over to the monitor, carefully avoiding anything sticky or the many menacing electrical discharges spouting from consoles.

Branded on top of screen are the words "Ventico ShortRange: 0 - 500". You think you glimpse a frame of information in the garbled output.

[Stare deeply into the static for 5 seconds]

Is that...can you make something our there, can I...

Meta.title: How to make rainbow rollovers in CSS
Meta.body:
How to create infinitely repeating rainbow rollovers in CSS (SASS)


You may have noticed that this site has some nifty rollovers that cycle through five colours. Some people think they are ugly; how little they know...

This is pretty easy to achieve in CSS:

1. First, choose your colours, however many you like. I used this site to pick some particularly nifty ones. We're going to be all 2013 about it and use SCSS variables.

2. Now that we have our colours, we need to create keyframes of each different colour to cycle through when we rollover an element. Make your increments regular, and remember to finish on the same colour that you started on so you don't get a jump.

3. Once the keyframes are setup it's just a matter of adding the animation on the rollover of our links.


Et voila: infinitely changing colour rollovers. You can apply this method to anything really; the top bar of the site is also cycling through these colours over 90 seconds.

Meta.title: Panto 2013: Donation to the Julian Trust Homeless Shelter
Meta.body:
Panto 2013: Donation to the Julian Trust Homeless Shelter


The last two years that we have put on Bristol's finest pantomime we've also had a little fundraiser to get some cash to buy some props and fund my increasingly expensive drug habit (J0KES LULZ).

This year Christophe, Lukas, and Pardon My French all graced the decks completely for free (so big up all themselves) at the Big Chill back in December. It was a top night, and thanks to all who came down.

We once again raised more money than we spent on the Panto (which you proabably worked out if you saw it), and have finally got our shiz together and donated it to the Julian Trust homeless shelter in Portland Square, Bristol.

We gave them Â£335, which isn't too shabby considering this is a seperate pot to the money raised on the actual day of the panto. So, once again massive thanks to everyone who put in the long hours that and hard work that our (my) lackadaisical preparation schedule necessitates.

Please like our Facebook page to hear about more exciting things like this blog post :/

NB yeah okay we only raised enough money for them to run for a fifth of a week, but that is better than nothing.

NB#2 I didn't ask them to just thank me in the letter. I honestly didn't.

Meta.title: Title
Meta.body:
Easter Eggs in games: What, Why, but really Why?


Last October my esteemed colleague Daniel Efergan and myself gave a talk about Easter Eggs in video games at the very excellent Playful 2014 conference in London.

The theme of the conference was 'Hidden', and the organisers from Mudlark asked us to talk about something personal to us; they didn't want some thinly veiled product placement (and neither did we). Dan and I both grew up playing and still play a lot of games, so the idea of hidden things instantly made us think of Easter Eggs.

After defining between ourselves that Easter Eggs in the context of games are something hidden that falls outside of the normal rule set of a game (i.e. doesn't necessarily reward or progress the player), we originally thought we would be talking all about game developers and ego. People obviously want to make a mark on the world, especialy a world that they have created. However, after thinking and talking about it every Wednesday lunchtime at Spike Island for two months, that had shifted quite a lot.

We came to believe that although this is true, it is actually a much more interesting emotional response that the joy Easter Eggs illicit comes from. The reason devlopers create them and the reason people feel so much joy in uncovering them is based on our own desires to break out of the rules set we ourselves currently inhabit.

We may have gone to wanky and deep, but watch the talk, see what you think.

Meta.title: Room 4b
Meta.body:
You walk away from the blinking of the monitor, through the devestation, towards what you presume must be the exit of the cockpit.

The metal portal at the end is the seemingly the only intact thing in the room. Your weight pressing against it yields nothing.

Disappointed, you start to turn...Is disappointment the first emotion you have felt since waking up? It seems strange that in a scene of horror and unimaginable violence, the disappointment of an steadfast door is what has first piqued inside you.

Pondering this strange malaise in your emotions, you walk toward the flickering monitor in the far corner.

Meta.title: HTML5 Games: A Producer's take...
Meta.body:
HTML5 Games:
Or, how I learned to stop worrying and love the browser


I ran a little training session for some of the other Producers and Produciton assisstants at Aardman about what I knew about making HTML5 games...this is it!

Weâre going to learn about making 2D games with Phaser, but there are plenty of other ways to make online games!

First of allâ¦

  • They are not really âHTML5 gamesâ! This is just a catch all term invented by the âmediaâ. HTML5 is the most recent HTML spec, with new features and ways of doing things.

  • They are actually comprised of lots of browser features like WebGL, JavaScript, GLSL, Web Audio, Canvas, DOM, CSS3 etcâ¦

When should I make an HTML5 games?

  • When you want a game that can run in the browser on desktop, tablet, and mobile.

  • You can also make an app by wrapping the code up in something like CocoonJS

  • â¦but if an app is your primary platform then you should probably be thinking about Unity, with an option of the WebGL export for a browser version.

What if I want to support IE8?

  • Then you will need to do everything in the DOM (see below) and not use canvas; this means NO PHASER!

  • But donât do thisâ¦IE8 is OLD. Some schools might be stuck on this because of archaic IT policy and machines, but it is terrible.

So what is an âhtml5â game made of?

Phaser

  • Is a game framework developed by our ex-tech direction, Rich Davey. Itâs very good.

  • It can deal with lots of the stuff you will need to do out of the box, and is completely free!

HTML, CSS, JS: THE BUILD

  • The live build of your game will be comprised to three elements:

      • o HTML: this is the actual nodes on the page, the building blocks on any webpage. In a Phaser game this will be a <canvas> element with a width and a height, which is a lump of plain graphics data of that size. You might add other HTML things over the top if you like: text forms, alerts, etc. This what people are referring to when they talk about the DOM (Document Object Model). In BBC games, things like the âRotate your Deviceâ message have to be HTML. You can create whole games in the DOM, using just HTML and CSS, but that is generally if you need to support something weird.

      o CSS: this is used for styling HTML elements, which otherwise just be rendered as the browser draws them. This would most normally be used for styling the embed of your game, or any other HTML elements you have included.

      o JS: and this does all the hardwork! Javascript creates, renders and manipulates everything inside your HTML <canvas> element.

      o JSON: is basically a spreadsheet. It should store all your text content which is rendered in the game, and also config settings, so things can be changed easily by your or the client without having to re-build the thing. This is especially good with the BBC, as you can tweak text and configuration without having to go through tech review again!

Whatâs all this WebGL nonsense then?

  • WebGL is a rendering engine that allows the browser to have GPU accelerated graphics in a web-game.

  • The GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) is part of a computer or device specifically designed for drawing graphics quickly and efficiently, and thus removes the burden from the CPU
    • (central processing unit).

  • WebGL can also do lots of cool stuff that a normal canvas element cannot:

    • o GLSL, which is a shader language allowing you to do cool visual effects over all or part of your canvas. See some examples here: http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/examples/15/indexAll.html

    o 3D! Using something like three.js: http://threejs.org/

    o Dynamic lighting! Thought weâve never tried this yet, http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/pixilights/

    o Boned animation! Little bits of asset, which are then manipulated on the fly using maths.

    o Probably loads more!

  • So how do I use it? If you are using Phaser, you are! Phaser uses the pixi.js renderer, which uses WebGL, and falls back to canvas if it is not available.

    • Typescript, grunt, assets, etc: THE SOURCE

  • Typescript: compiles to javascript, but is statically typed. (I think) this means it checks at compile time whether you are passing the correct type of thing into your
    • variable (number, string, etc), and tells you if there is a problem. There are probably other things, but this is what I know about it.

  • Grunt: is a taskrunner, and what we use to build the project. It takes all the source files and turns them into the build, and you can configure it do any part of the
    • process you like e.g.

    o Compile TS to JS

    o RequireJS (which loads in modules, librarys etc into one file)

    o Remove unneeded files

    o Minification (removing all the whitespace from your code to make it smaller)

    o Optimise images

    o FTP deploy to the server

  • Images

    • o Images: will graphics will be sprite based, usually PNGs

    o Animations will be sequences of PNGs that play one after another

    o All your images should be compiled into (preferably) one spritesheet â a big sheet of all the images, and a reference in the game. Use a program like TexturePacker to squeeze them in as tightly as possible.

    Â§ Why one spritesheet? Unloading and loading sheets into memory is processor intensive for a device. If it can just load one into memory and thatâs it, amazing!

    Â§ Spritehsheets should be Power of 2 e.g. 512 x 512, 1024 x 1024, 2048 x 2048, etc. This is the sizes that GPUs use, and should make your game more performant (though if not using WebGL it doesnât matter).

  • Sound

    • o Is a lot better than it used to be!

    o Web Audio supports polyphonic sound, effects like reverb and more

    o Internet Explorer and older Android browsers still an issue - Phaser sound falls back to the older Audio API, so it can only play one sound at a time

    o Should effects should be concatenated into sound sprites, which is one long track with all the sounds in, with a time reference for each one.

    o You need MP3 and OGG versions of your sounds.

    o Music should be as individual looping sounds, and kept as short as possible.

    o Use Soundsprite to create them: https://www.npmjs.com/package/soundsprite

    Other things!

  • Libraries:

    • o There are plenty of good open source javascript libraries for doing lots of cool things. Some we have used on DMK include:

    Â§ Hammer: for touch gestures

    Â§ Underscore: extends javascript with lots of new functionality you donât need to write

    Â§ jQuery: same as above

    Â§ JSONpack: for compressing JSON files so they could be emailed (long story)

  • IDEs for Javascript/Typescript:

    • o If they use something like IntelliJ or Visual Studio Code will make life a lot easier for your developers: error highlighting, lookups, hints for Typescript.

    things to be aware ofâ¦

  • Performance is always an issue on devices. Save lots of time for optimising your game, and make sure you test it on devices throughout the build process, not
    • just at the end!

  • iOS for some reason needs a touch/click event before it will play any sound. Make sure you have one of these before anything important happens in your game!

  • All browsers will perform differently, so again, leave lots of time for testing. REMEMBER that Twitter and Facebook both have their own internal browsers now. 50% of
    • the mobile traffic to Eastenders Storyteller is the Facebook internal browser! FFS!

  • Accessibility for the blind (e.g. tab controls and screen readers) has been bad for a while in Phaser and canvas games in general, as the tools rely on the DOM to be
    • read. The way to get around this is to make all the UI as DOM elements and overlay the phaser canvas with them. (See Something Special and Deadly Defenders.)

  • File size, mobile games may be loaded over mobile networks and we should take care to not over use end usersâ data plans. Libraries like require js can help by
    • minifying and combining all the javascript, but content is the real killer.

  • Scope, The DMK projects are the exception as opposed to the rule. It is best to have a good mechanic that is well polished than lots of content, which will damage
    • performance, and increase filesize. KISS!
